Award.AwardTitle: Fiber-Optic Technology for Fully-Distributed Physical, Chemical, and Biological Sensing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the project is to develop an optical fiber sensor technology that will enable fully-distributed simultaneous measurement of physical, chemical, and biological parameters in a single fiber. This approach is based on a novel traveling long period grating (LPG), generated either acoustically or optically in a single-mode fiber. The spatially-localized traveling grating couples the guided optical mode in the fiber core to cladding modes, which then interact with functional coatings on the surface of the fiber to cause the transmitted optical spectrum to shift. Unlike traditional LPGs, which are limited to single-point measurement, the traveling LPG enables fully-distributed sensing. By partitioning of different surface coatings, each of which can have selective response to different parameters, a variety of physical, chemical, and biological parameters can be measured with a single fiber.

This research will culminate in a full system demonstration for distributed measurement of various physical, chemical, and biological parameters with one fiber. Future applications of this work include pollution detection in rivers and lakes, chemical-bio terrorism agent detection for a variety of public venues, hydrogen detection in future hydrogen energy systems, and leak detection in long pipelines for various gaseous or liquid chemical delivery.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed to generate a travelling long period grating on optical fiber for distributed physical, chemical and biological sensing. A traditional long period grating is a periodical structure on an optical fiber that can be used to monitor physical, chemical and biological parameters in the fiber surrounding environment. Traditional long period gratings are generally manufactured by inscribing permanent refractive index changes inside an optical fiber typically with high intensity laser. These long period gratings are thus static and permanent and are only as a point sensor.

What we did in this project is to change the long period grating generation mechanism from static to dynamic. An piezoelectric element and an acoustic horn are used to focus a strong elastic wave onto a bare optical fiber. This periodical elastic wave then induces refractive index changes along the sensing fiber, which consequently forms a long period grating that travels with the speed of the elastic wave aong the fiber. Based on this method, we successfully demonstrated distributed sensing of temperature, hydrogen and immunoglobulin G.  Nine meters of sesing span was achieved.

Beside these technical achievements, this project also supported three graduate students and produced three journal publications plus another one under preparation. Among these three graduate students, one has earned her PhD degree, one was granted a M.S. degree and the third is still pursuing a PhD degree at Virginia Tech.
